CatDescriptText: Cornelius Taylor, employee, Pat's Place Confectionery, Fifth Ward and John L. Washington, postal clerk, Third Ward, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, October 28, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., should come to Pittsburgh and take over the pastorate of a church, or should he remain in the South and continue his crusade?    Mr. Taylor's answer reads: "He should stay in the South and continue the crusade there against white supremacy.  If he gets away, there are a lot of things which he is doing which others will not have the nerve to do.  Nobody can fill his shoes, and all the South knows this, and what he means...They also know that nobody can scare him."  Mr. Washington's answer reads: "He should stay in the South, because he can do more good there than here.  He can reach  more people there..."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Cornelius Taylor wearing patterned necktie, eyeglasses, and hat, standing with hands behind back in front of automobiles and buildings; Portrait of John L. Washington wearing varsity jacket with "N" and United States Navy patch, standing with hands behind back
